content: The Act titled "Veterans Medicare Reimbursement Demonstration Act of 1997" establishes a demonstration project. The Act titled "Veterans Medicare Reimbursement Demonstration Act of 1997" establishes a demonstration project where the Secretary of Health and Human Services provides reimbursement from the medicare program for health care services provided to targeted medicare-eligible veterans in facilities of the Department of Veterans Affairs. The demonstration project under the "Veterans Medicare Reimbursement Demonstration Act of 1997" allows reimbursement from the medicare program for health care services provided to targeted medicare-eligible veterans in VA facilities. The project will run for three years starting from January 1, 1998, with the Secretary of Health and Human Services having the authority to waive certain medicare requirements if needed. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may waive certain Medicare requirements to carry out the demonstration project. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will designate up to three geographic service areas for facility selection in the project. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will designate up to three geographic service areas for facility selection in a demonstration project. The selection of facilities will be done in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will establish a plan for selecting facilities within designated geographic service areas to participate in the project. The selection plan will prioritize facilities suited to serve targeted Medicare-eligible individuals due to high potential demand. The selection plan for facilities in designated geographic service areas will prioritize those suited to serve targeted Medicare-eligible individuals due to high potential demand and capability in billing and accounting. The selection plan prioritizes facilities with high potential demand from targeted Medicare-eligible veterans, sufficient billing capability, quality care indicators, and meeting relevant factors. At least one facility near a closed base will be selected. The selection plan prioritizes facilities based on potential demand from targeted Medicare-eligible veterans, billing capability, quality care indicators, and relevant factors. At least one facility near a closed military base will be chosen. The demonstration project targets Medicare-eligible veterans near closed military bases, with voluntary participation. The demonstration project under Title II of the Defense Authorization Amendments and Base Closure and Realignment Act allows voluntary participation of targeted Medicare-eligible veterans, with cost-sharing requirements similar to those at nongovernmental facilities. The Secretary will establish cost-sharing requirements for veterans in the demonstration project, similar to those for targeted Medicare-eligible patients at nongovernmental facilities. Payments received will be credited to the Department of Veterans Affairs medical appropriation. The Secretary will determine reimbursement amounts for veterans in the demonstration project, following cost-sharing requirements similar to those for targeted Medicare-eligible patients at nongovernmental facilities. Payments received will be credited to the Department of Veterans Affairs medical appropriation. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will reimburse the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for services provided under the demonstration project at a rate equal to 95 percent of the amounts that would be payable under the Medicare program for such services. The Secretaries will reimburse the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for services provided under the demonstration project at a rate equal to 95 percent of the amounts that would be payable under the Medicare program for such services. Payments under this section will be made on a periodic basis consistent with the periodicity of payments under the Medicare program. The Secretaries will establish rules for computing payment amounts, made periodically from Medicare trust funds. Payments will be made from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. There will be an annual limit on Medicare payments. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will determine payments from Medicare trust funds for a demonstration project with the Department of Veterans Affairs. The annual limit for payments under this project is $50,000,000. Failure by the VA to maintain effort may result in a reduction in payment to avoid shifting costs onto the Medicare program. The annual limit for the demonstration project with the Department of Veterans Affairs is $50,000,000. Payment amounts may be reduced if the VA fails to maintain effort to prevent shifting costs to the Medicare program. The annual limit for the project may be reduced based on actual VA medical expenditures for targeted veterans compared to the maintenance of effort level. Maintenance of effort level is determined based on the preceding fiscal year. The maintenance of effort level for any fiscal year is the amount equal to the maintenance of effort level for the preceding fiscal year or the amount of VA medical expenditures for targeted veterans for fiscal year 1997, adjusted by the same percentage change. The maintenance of effort level for a fiscal year is adjusted based on the percentage change in the medical care appropriation for the Department of Veterans Affairs compared to the preceding fiscal year. The maintenance of effort level for a fiscal year is adjusted based on the percentage change in the VA medical care appropriation compared to the previous fiscal year, and is also influenced by any decrease in VA medical expenditures for targeted veterans. The maintenance of effort level for a fiscal year is adjusted based on the percentage change in the VA medical care appropriation compared to the previous fiscal year, and is also influenced by any decrease in VA medical expenditures for targeted veterans resulting from a lower rate of increase in medical care appropriations for the Department of Veterans Affairs. The reduction in priority in delivery of services to targeted medicare-eligible veterans is due to lower medical care appropriations for the Department of Veterans Affairs. The VA is reducing services for targeted Medicare-eligible veterans due to lower medical care appropriations. VA medical expenditures for targeted veterans are defined as the amount spent by the Department in a fiscal year. The plan developed under Public Law 104-204 defines VA medical expenditures for targeted Medicare-eligible veterans as the amount spent by the Department of Veterans Affairs in a fiscal year for hospital care and medical services under chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code. The Department of Veterans Affairs spent an amount in a fiscal year for hospital care and medical services for targeted Medicare-eligible veterans, excluding certain expenditures. The Department of Veterans Affairs monitors expenditures under the Medicare program for targeted Medicare-eligible veterans to ensure no increase in costs compared to what would have been spent without the demonstration project. The Comptroller General closely monitors expenditures under the Medicare program for targeted Medicare-eligible veterans during the demonstration project to compare with what would have been spent without the project. The Comptroller General audits these expenditures annually and reports to the Secretaries. The Comptroller General audits Medicare program expenditures for targeted veterans annually during the demonstration project to assess any cost increases. The Secretaries of Health and Human Services must report to Congress on any increase in costs under the Medicare program due to a demonstration project. If costs have increased, they are required to respond accordingly. If Medicare program costs increase due to a demonstration project, the Secretaries must recoup the amount and prevent future increases. The Secretaries must recoup any increase in Medicare program costs and prevent future increases by taking necessary steps, including payment from the Department of Veterans Affairs appropriation to the trust funds. The Secretaries must recoup any increase in Medicare program costs by paying from the Department of Veterans Affairs appropriation to the trust funds and taking necessary steps to prevent future increases. The Secretaries must recoup any increase in Medicare program costs by paying from the Department of Veterans Affairs appropriation to the trust funds and taking necessary steps to prevent future increases, including suspending or terminating the demonstration project or substituting a lower percentage for 95 percent under subsection (a)(1). SEC. 4. EVALUATION AND REPORTS. An independent entity will evaluate a health services demonstration project annually and submit reports to the Secretaries and Congress by March 1 each year. The reports will include assessments of the project's results. Each year, an independent entity will evaluate a health services demonstration project and submit reports to Congress by March 1. The reports will assess the cost to the Department of Veterans Affairs and the compliance of participating facilities with quality measures compared to other medicare-participating facilities. The evaluation of a health services demonstration project includes assessing the cost to the Department of Veterans Affairs, compliance of participating facilities with quality measures, comparison of costs with reimbursements, impact on Medicare programs, and changes in access to care or quality of care. The evaluation of a health services demonstration project includes comparing costs with reimbursements, assessing impact on Medicare programs, and evaluating changes in access to care or quality of care for targeted Medicare-eligible veterans. The evaluation of a health services demonstration project includes assessing changes in access to care or quality of care for targeted Medicare-eligible veterans. A report on the extension and expansion of the project will be submitted to Congress within six months after the final report. The Secretaries will report to Congress within six months on whether to extend or make permanent the health services demonstration project, expand it to cover more sites and increase reimbursement amounts, and whether to continue or modify project terms if extended or expanded. The Secretaries will report to Congress on whether to extend or make permanent the health services demonstration project, expand it to cover more sites, increase reimbursement amounts, and continue or modify project terms if extended or expanded. Additionally, a report on the feasibility of establishing a new demonstration project for payment to Managed Health-Care Plans will be submitted by March 1, 1999. The Secretaries will report to Congress on the feasibility of a new demonstration project for payment to Managed Health-Care Plans by March 1, 1999. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The terms "demonstration project" and "project" refer to the project under section 2(a). The term "geographic service area" is a field component of the Veterans Health Administration based on a geographic area serving veteran beneficiaries through strategic alliances. The administration is based on a geographic area serving veteran beneficiaries through strategic alliances among Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers, clinics, and other sites. The term "medicare program" refers to health benefits provided under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. Alliances among Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers, clinics, and other sites are established to serve veteran beneficiaries. The term "medicare program" refers to health benefits provided under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, and "Secretaries" refers to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the Secretary of Health and Human Services acting jointly. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, and "Secretaries" refers to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the Secretary of Health and Human Services acting jointly. A "targeted medicare-eligible veteran" is an individual who is a veteran described in specific sections of title 38, United States Code, and entitled to hospital insurance benefits. A "targeted medicare-eligible veteran" is a veteran entitled to hospital insurance benefits under Medicare, with income between specified thresholds. Veterans eligible for Medicare Part A and enrolled in Part B, with income between specified thresholds.
